p: The interferon (IFN) response constitutes the major first line of defense against viruses. Recognition of viral infections by innate immune sensors activates type I and type III IFN response. Type I IFNs (IFN-α, IFN-β, IFN-ε, IFN-κ, IFN-ω in humans) bind to the ubiquitously expressed type I IFN receptor (IFNAR) in an autocrine and paracrine manner. This activates a powerful antiviral defense program of hundreds of interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs), which have the capacity to interfere with every step of viral replication ( Schoggins and Rice, 2011). Type III IFNs (IFN-λ) bind to the type III IFN receptor (IFNLR), preferentially expressed on epithelial cells and certain myeloid cells ( Kotenko et al., 2019). Whereas type I and III IFNs induce a similar ISG signature, type I IFN signaling leads to a more rapid induction and decline of ISG expression ( Lazear et al., 2019).
